response.answer_text: For me the greatest American naval hero has to be the Union Admiral David Farragut (1801–1870).  In Farragut’s case, I’m thinking not only of his great personal courage, but also of his tactical and strategic insight and his great moral courage. He had the nerve to plan, undertake, and personally lead two of the most dangerous and successful nautical undertakings of the American Civil War, in each case leading to a decisive and indispensable Union victory. The first of these victories was the Capture of New Orleans, which fell to Farragut’s fleet in April 1962 after Farragut broke through a powerful—and some thought invincible—ring of Confederate fortifications and defensive vessels. The capture of New Orleans was among the most decisive Union victories of the Civil War, since it closed the South’s largest port and center of trade to the Confederacy—and opened it to the Union. This capture was also the first step toward the Union’s achievement of total control of the Mississippi with the fall of Vicksburg in July 1863. Below we see a dramatic depiction of Farragut’s flagship, the USS Hartford, forcing its way past Fort Jackson and the feared Confederate ironclad ram Manassas. 2. The second of these victories was Farragut’s success at the Battle of Mobile Bay. In 1864, the Confederacy’s last major port on the Caribbean was at Mobile, Alabama. Mobile Bay was protected by a trio of powerful forts, mounting heavy cannon, as well as by an extensive field of tethered naval mines (then called “torpedoes”) controlling all but a narrow passage in the one navigable channel, which ran past Fort Morgan, the Bay’s largest fortress. To be clear: in order to enter the Bay, Farragut’s fleet of mostly wooden ships would have to steam through a narrow thread of water with the massive Fort Morgan on one side and that minefield of floating, tethered torpedoes on the other. Once past the Fort Morgan, Farragut’s fleet would face the heavily armored, if slow moving, Confederate ironclad Tennessee. Again, a dramatic painting sets the scene:  Farragut had himself lashed high in the rigging on the mast of his flagship, the Hartford. When his lead ironclad, the Tecumseh (just beginning to heel over in the picture above) hit a torpedo and sank with almost all hands, the following ships began to mill around and falter—leaving them as easy targets for Fort Morgan’s guns. From his perch in the rigging, Farragut called down to his staff on the Hartford with the words "Damn the torpedoes! Four bells. Captain Drayton, go ahead! Jouett, full speed!" These words have been shortened in common parlance to the popular saying: “Damn the torpedoes! Full speed ahead.” Farragut’s exploits, and his way with words, made for a great recruiting poster.  Despite taking many hits from the guns on Fort Morgan, Farragut’s Hartford and the balance of his fleet succeeded in penetrating Mobile Bay and subduing the ironclad Tennessee. Later, Farragut’s navy, with the aid of amphibious infantry who approached the fortress from the landward side, combined to compel the surrender of Fort Morgan—and, as of August 1864, Mobile Bay was in Union hands. Thanks to Farragut’s careful planning, willingness to accept risk, and courageous personal leadership, the Union navy won two of its most important victories of the Civil War. I think America’s greatest Admiral was Chester W. Nimitz, whose performance in the Pacific during WWII was spectacular. But America’s greatest naval hero was David Farragut.

At first that would be given to John Paul Jones. Who gave the naval battle cry “I have not yet begun to fight.” But for me it has to be Raymond Ames Spruance. He was basically thrown into command of Admiral Hulsey’s carrier fleet. Never in command of a fleet that size(carrier-air combat). He commanded four heavy cruisers and support ships at the time Hulsey recommended him to Admiral Nimitz. That put him in charge of Task Force 16 which included “USS Enterprise and USS Hornet.” The “Yorktown” under Jack Fletcher also included in this battle. In the battle for “Midway” ,through his command leadership the US Navy sank all 4 Japanese carriers. Losing only the “Yorktown.” But that in itself being important the most important thing that occurred was this put and end to the Japanese Naval (IJN) threat to the Pacific. Helping put the US on a path to victory. By stopping them at Midway, gave time for the US to catch up with building of ships and supplies. Spruance is to me the “greatestAmerican naval war hero.
